key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal drug/protein data with per-sample out-of-distribution (OOD) uncertainty estimates to substantially improve binding-affinity predictions across multiple targets, enabling safer, more reliable polypharmacology assessment.
problem_solved: Existing affinity predictors struggle with compounds that act on multiple targets and fail silently on out-of-distribution examples; this work addresses reliable prediction plus calibrated, individual uncertainty for each compound–target pair.
method: Multimodal input fusion: integrates molecular representations (structures/SMILES), protein features (sequence/structure), and assay/context data into a unified model.
Per-sample OOD-aware uncertainty quantification: produces calibrated uncertainty scores for each prediction to flag unreliable/novel compound–target pairs.

Architecture & training: a joint model (eMOSAIC) that learns cross-modal interactions while optimizing for both accuracy and uncertainty calibration to improve generalization in polypharmacology settings.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners in drug discovery a practical framework to make risk-aware affinity predictions, prioritize experiments, and reduce costly failures by explicitly surfacing when model outputs are uncertain or out-of-distribution.

paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
